net.cloud.gfx.elements.decorator

Class DraggableElement

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.cloud.gfx.elements.decorator.AbstractDecoratorElement
      • net.cloud.gfx.elements.decorator.DraggableElement
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DecoratorElement, Element, Focusable

    public class DraggableElement
extends AbstractDecoratorElement
    An element which when dragged, will move around the screen. This decorator adds that behavior to another element. Then this reference may be used in place of the original element for outside functionality, such as mouse and key events. This decorator treats the wrapped element and itself nearly one and the same, using the wrapped element to maintain functionality.

    The ability to move the element may be toggled, as well as where on the element will allow the dragging and within what bounds the element can be moved. By default these are toggled on, from anywhere, and within the parent, respectively.

    • Field Detail

      • enabled

        private boolean enabled
        Flag for whether or not dragging is currently enabled

      • dragBounds

        private java.util.Optional<java.awt.Rectangle> dragBounds
        The bounds this element must stay within. If not specified, uses the parent.

      • startBounds

        private java.util.Optional<java.util.LinkedList<java.awt.Rectangle>> startBounds
        The various bounding boxes where dragging may be started from. If not specified, this is anywhere.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DraggableElement

        public DraggableElement(Element toDecorate)
        Create a new DraggableElement by wrapping functionality around an existing element. By default, dragging will be enabled, from anywhere, within the parent.
        Parameters:
        toDecorate - The element to wrap around

      • DraggableElement

        public DraggableElement(Element toDecorate,
                        boolean enabled,
                        java.awt.Rectangle withinBounds,
                        java.awt.Rectangle... fromBounds)
        Full constructor, where everything is specified.
        Parameters:
        toDecorate - The element to wrap around
        enabled - True if dragging is enabled
        withinBounds - The bounding box the element must stay in. May be null for within parent.
        fromBounds - All of the bounding boxes defining where on the element dragging may be started from. May be null.

    • Method Detail

      • dragged

        public void dragged(Element dragged,
                    java.awt.Point start,
                    java.awt.Point withinStart,
                    java.awt.Point current)
        Moves the element when it is dragged. No matter the result, the wrapped element will have its dragged method called as well. Dragging must be enabled, and the withinStart point must be within one of the starting rectangles. Further, the element cannot be moved beyond its bounds. It will instead snug up against them.
        Specified by:
        dragged in interface Element
        Overrides:
        dragged in class AbstractDecoratorElement
        Parameters:
        dragged - The element that was dragged. It may not be this element!
        start - Where the dragging started. I.e. where the mouse was first pressed down
        withinStart - The point within the element dragging started. Like with the other mouse events.
        current - Where the mouse is currently at. Can be used to find a movement delta or used directly.

      • setEnabled

        public void setEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Set whether or not dragging is enabled on this element
        Parameters:
        enabled - True if dragging is okay, false if it should not happen

      • setDragBounds

        public void setDragBounds(java.awt.Rectangle dragBounds)
        Set the bounds that define where the element may be moved to. This is essentially relative to the parent element. Can be set to null to restrict to the parent in a dynamic manner, or to a very large range to allow movement essentially anywhere.
        Parameters:
        dragBounds - The bounding box the element must stay in. May be null for within parent.

      • addStartBound

        public void addStartBound(java.awt.Rectangle startBound)
        Add a bounding rectangle defining where dragging may originate from. For example, in a framed element, it is useful to add the top border of the frame as a start bound. Multiple bounds may be set, and if the start point is within any of them, dragging will be allowed. They can be removed, via the rectangle or a point.
        Parameters:
        startBound - A bounding on where dragging may be started from

      • removeStartBound

        public void removeStartBound(java.awt.Rectangle startBound)
        Remove a starting bound, by providing an equivalent rectangle. The provided rectangle must be an equals(Object obj) match. Only the first match will be removed. This will do nothing if there are no start bounds
        Parameters:
        startBound - The bounding rectangle to remove

      • removeStartBound

        public void removeStartBound(java.awt.Point startPoint)
        Remove all starting bounds which contain the given point. This will remove all such bounds, not just the first occurrence. This will do nothing if there are no start bounds
        Parameters:
        startPoint - A point whose matching start bounds will be removed

      • getBoundedX

        private int getBoundedX(int destX)
        Get an x coordinate which is within bounds. If the coordinate would otherwise be out of bounds, an edge is returned. Otherwise, the same coordinate is given back.
        Parameters:
        destX - The unbounded destination coordinate
        Returns:
        A bounded and valid destination coordinate

      • getBoundedY

        private int getBoundedY(int destY)
        Get an x coordinate which is within bounds. If the coordinate would otherwise be out of bounds, an edge is returned. Otherwise, the same coordinate is given back.
        Parameters:
        destY - The unbounded destination coordinate
        Returns:
        A bounded and valid destination coordinate
